author: By Laura Zornosa
title: Dispatch Has Rereleased ‘The General’ in Russian to Support Ukraine
description: The band members Chadwick Stokes and Brad Corrigan said they hope that Russian soldiers will hear the antiwar song and discontinue their invasion.
content: The roots rock band Dispatch on Tuesday rereleased its popular antiwar anthem, “The General,” after recording it in Russian in hopes, the band said, that Russian soldiers might hear the song and its message and “question their role” in the Ukrainian invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Political Satirist Stewart Wins the Twain Prize for Humor
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, April 26, 2022.
content: “Comedy doesn’t change the world, but it’s a bellwether. We’re the banana peel in the coal mine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: French Lessons for the Biden Administration
description: Macron’s victory is a reminder to Democrats to find the center on immigration.
content: You probably breathed a deep sigh of relief when you heard that Emmanuel Macron trounced Marine Le Pen by a 17-point margin in Sunday’s French presidential election. A Le Pen victory would have been a boon to Vladimir Putin, Viktor Orban and Steve Bannon and a disaster for NATO, Europe and France.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cristal Duhaime
title: A ‘Cruiser’ Sets Sail, Despite Covid
description: A return to the sea means a return to life for one die-hard cruiser.
content: For those who love to be on the seas, the past two years have been tough. In early 2020, as the coronavirus spread across the globe, cruise ships became petri dishes for the disease. By mid-March that year, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued an order that effectively shut down the industry — and it stayed shuttered for more than a year. For people who make cruising a lifestyle, not just a pastime, being marooned on land was devastating. Charles Falls Jr., known as Chillie, is one of those cruisers who set sail as much as possible. He has been on 55 cruises and in recent years started hosting a YouTube show about the industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Hotels With Net-Zero Ambitions
description: It’s not easy for sustainability-minded travelers to find truly green accommodations, but these new hotels — one of which claims to be the first net-zero carbon emissions hotel in the country — are aiming high.
content: Many global travelers, it appears, want to tour more sustainably. In its annual survey on sustainability, the hotel platform Booking.com recently found 71 percent of respondents planned to travel greener, up 10 percent over 2021 results. More than half say they are more determined to make environmentally responsible travel choices this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Robinhood says it will lay off 9% of its employees.
description: The company’s co-founder Vlad Tenev said it had overhired during the height of the pandemic, and now needed to “increase our velocity.”
content: Robinhood, the app that popularized free one-click trading of stocks and options, said on Tuesday that it was laying off approximately 340 people, or about 9 percent of its 3,800 employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: Classical Music Doesn’t Have to Be Ugly to Be Good
description: Melodious isn’t unsophisticated.
content: In the early 1990s, I was in a chorus assigned to sing a contemporary classical piece that was, in a word, hideous. Almost willfully so, it seemed. It wasn’t in any home key — it was atonal — giving the listener no sense of base, instead just creeping all over the sonic spectrum. To my ear, the piece offered nothing of beauty, sequence or proportion. I remember thinking that I would rather have listened to a silverware drawer thrown down a staircase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Struggles Over Biden’s Bid to End ‘Remain in Mexico’ Program
description: Known formally as the Migrant Protection Protocols, the program, adopted during the Trump administration, requires some migrants to wait in Mexico while their cases are heard.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court appeared frustrated on Tuesday during arguments over whether the Biden administration can end a Trump-era immigration program that forces asylum seekers arriving at the southwestern border to await approval in Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Queer in Appalachia’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: “Family Size” was written in an aggressively large font on my Cheerios box. As I poured myself a second bowl, alone at 4 p.m. on Easter Sunday, the message reminded me that I don’t have a family (and, therefore, little need for such a big box). Divorce can cause this cynical perspective to descend at surprising times. My ex-husband and I met three weeks before my mother died when I was 22. I saw our love as security. Her death broke me — our divorce transformed me. I’m not afraid anymore. Rather, I’m filling myself up with self-love, self-reliance and Cheerios. — Amy Culleton Leslie
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: The Major Findings of Harvard’s Report on Its Ties to Slavery
description: Harvard University issued a 134-page report investigating its ties to slavery, and its legacy. Here are the key findings.
content: In 2019, Harvard’s president, Lawrence S. Bacow, appointed a committee of faculty members to investigate the university’s ties to slavery, as well as its legacy. Discussions about race were intensifying across the country. Students were demanding that the names of people involved in the slave trade be removed from buildings. Other universities, notably Brown, had already conducted similar excavations of their past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Celtics Eliminate Nets’ Latest Superteam With First-Round Sweep
description: The early playoff exit was a stunning end to a season that began with championship dreams behind Kevin Durant and Kyrie Irving.
content: The basketball zings from player to player when the Celtics run their offense, and it found Grant Williams as the first half was winding down in Game 4 of Boston’s first-round playoff series against the Nets on Monday night at Barclays Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Muses on Elon Musk’s Deal to Buy Twitter
description: Trevor Noah joked that owning Twitter would give Musk “more power than the drugstore employee with the key to the deodorant shelf.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Youngest Guantánamo Detainee Is Cleared for Release
description: Hassan bin Attash, who has been held since 2002 without charge, now needs a transfer deal. His brother, also at Guantánamo, is accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — The youngest detainee at Guantánamo Bay, a Yemeni man who has spent his entire adult life in U.S. custody, has been cleared for release, the Pentagon disclosed on Tuesday, but must wait for the Biden administration to find a country willing to offer him rehabilitation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Buying Twitter, Elon Musk Will Face Reality of His Free-Speech Talk
description: Tech’s big shots have learned again and again that free speech isn’t so simple. What happens when Mr. Musk owns Twitter?
content: A decade ago, Twitter executives, including the chief executive, Dick Costolo, declared that the social media site was the “free-speech wing of the free-speech party.” The stance meant Twitter would defend people’s ability to post whatever they wished and be heard by the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Fremson
title: An Assignment I Needed: Frederick Law Olmsted’s Legacy
description: A Times photographer spent a year traveling to public spaces designed by the 19th-century landscape architect.
content: One day in January, I stood on the 71st floor of 111 West 57th Street, a luxury skyscraper in Manhattan. Below me, Central Park was a vast, frosty oasis hemmed in by tall buildings. Skaters were followed by their shadows in the morning sunlight as they glided on the ice at Wollman Rink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trial Begins for Former N.Y.P.D. Officer on Jan. 6 Charges
description: A onetime member of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s security detail is accused of assaulting a Washington police officer during the Capitol riot.
content: Among the many violent scuffles that erupted during the riot at the Capitol, this one stood out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Janet Hook
title: Side by Side With (Bernie) Sanders
description: Ari Rabin-Havt’s “The Fighting Soul” provides a rare close-up of Bernie Sanders.
content: THE FIGHTING SOULOn the Road With Bernie SandersBy Ari Rabin-Havt
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Food, Fertilizer and the Future
description: Surprise: Old-style globalization is bearing the brunt of this crisis.
content: As anyone who drives is aware, gasoline prices are up a lot from their 2020 low. First, global economic recovery drove up oil demand, then Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine cut into Russian oil exports. But prices both at the pump and at the wellhead have stabilized, at least for now. By historical standards, real gas prices — prices relative to the overall cost of living — aren’t that high; in fact, they’re lower than they were from 2006 to 2014. And as of this morning, Texas crude oil was back below $100 a barrel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Do Vaccines Protect Against Long Covid?
description: Maybe, according to a growing number of studies, but there’s not yet a definitive answer.
content: As the pandemic enters its third year, long Covid has emerged as an increasingly important concern. And many people are wondering whether getting a Covid shot can reduce their chances of developing long-term symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: With Supply More Abundant, Pharmacies Struggle to Use Up Covid Pills
description: The White House on Tuesday announced new steps to expand access to Paxlovid, the Covid-19 antiviral pill. But experts say that efforts to reach at-risk Americans remain complex and inefficient.
content: GREENBELT, Md. — Last month, the owner of a small pharmacy here secured two dozen courses of Pfizer’s new medication for treating Covid-19, eager to quickly provide them to his high-risk customers who test positive for the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: Sasha Waltz’s ‘In C’ Marries Choreography and Improvisation
description: Waltz’s dance, born in deep lockdown, embraces the openness and fluidity of Terry Riley’s classic minimalist score. It’s coming to BAM.
content: BERLIN — “I started in the deep lockdown,” said the German choreographer Sasha Waltz. “Everything was closed. And it was in the winter. It was gray and everybody was depressed. And we said, we have to keep working. We cannot go on like this.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Mark Emmert to Step Down as President of the N.C.A.A.
description: Emmert and the N.C.A.A.’s Board of Governors said they made a mutual decision for him to step aside next year as the top administrator in college sports.
content: The N.C.A.A., buffeted by an erosion of its influence, years of courtroom acrimony and widening calls for a reset of the college sports industry that it has lately struggled to govern, said Tuesday that its president, Mark Emmert, would step down by the middle of next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: fallibility
description: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word fallibility has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 9 in “These Jennifer Aniston Fans Weren’t Born When ‘Friends’ Aired” by Ruth La Ferla:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Pasick
title: Raising the Stakes in Ukraine
description: The U.S. organizes military aid for Ukraine, as Russia warns a proxy war could lead to nuclear war.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: New Rules Will End the Century-Long Run of Classic Light Bulbs
description: The administration set efficiency standards that will phase out sales of incandescent bulbs in favor of LEDs, reducing Americans’ electrical bills over time.
content: After lighting the nation’s homes and businesses for more than a century, transforming the design of buildings and even lengthening the average workday, incandescent light bulbs are finally on their way out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Los Angeles Sheriff, Accused of Cover-Up, Opens Investigation Into Reporter
description: The sheriff said he was investigating the leak of a video that was reported on by The Los Angeles Times.
content: The Los Angeles County sheriff said on Tuesday that he was investigating a reporter at The Los Angeles Times who had reported allegations that he was involved in covering up a case of inmate abuse, an announcement that drew accusations that he was violating the reporter’s First Amendment rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Front-Runners in G.O.P. Pennsylvania Senate Race Are Put on Spot at Debate
description: Dr. Mehmet Oz and David McCormick, when not sparring with each other, faced attacks from three other challengers.
content: When the leading Republican candidates for Senate in Pennsylvania — the Trump-endorsed celebrity surgeon Dr. Mehmet Oz and David McCormick, a former hedge fund executive — shared a debate stage for the first time on Monday night, they faced sharp attacks not only from each other but also from three other candidates vying to chip away at their polling lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Donald Baechler, Painter of Cartoonish Collages, Is Dead at 65
description: His works, depicting crudely-drawn images of balloon-like faces, beach balls, flowers, globes or ice cream cones, brought him fame in New York in the 1980s.
content: Donald Baechler was part of one of the most exciting moments in postwar art in New York, the early 1980s, when talented artists, if usually male and young, were popping up all over the landscape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Mets Stun Cardinals With a Wild Ninth Inning Comeback
description: A strong start by Max Scherzer, a five-run ninth inning and positive news on the health of Jacob deGrom made for a great Monday.
content: ST. LOUIS — Pinch-hitter Dominic Smith hustled for an infield single that drove in two pivotal runs, and the Mets capitalized on an uncharacteristic error by Gold Glove third baseman Nolan Arenado to rally for five runs with two outs in the ninth inning of a 5-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Aishvarya Kavi
title: Vice President Harris Tests Positive for Coronavirus
description: While Kamala Harris had not seen President Biden for eight days, her positive test renewed concerns about his vulnerability to the virus.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Kamala Harris tested positive for the coronavirus on Tuesday, becoming the latest high-ranking official in Washington to be infected amid renewed concern about President Biden’s potential exposure as the virus ripples through his administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi and Constant Méheut
title: Convincing Victory Disguises Steep Challenges for Macron
description: France’s runoff election was marked by a record level of abstention, and many cast a ballot only to keep the far right from power — a testament to a growing disillusionment.
content: ROYE, France — There is no doubt that President Emmanuel Macron of France won a convincing re-election over Marine Le Pen, his far-right challenger, on Sunday. Mr. Macron scored a thumping 17 point margin of victory, becoming the first French leader to be re-elected to a second term in 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Sid Mark, Disc Jockey Devoted to Sinatra for Six Decades, Dies at 88
description: He hosted four radio shows that focused on the singer, who at one concert singled him out in the audience and said, “I love him.”
content: Sid Mark, a longtime disc jockey in Philadelphia who made Frank Sinatra’s songs the center of his musical universe for more than six decades, died on April 18 in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Little Free Libraries
description: Is there one near you? If you were in charge of a Little Free Library, what would it look like, and what would you give away?
content: Have you ever come across a Little Free Library in your neighborhood or anywhere else? There are over 100,000 of these miniature lending libraries around the globe where anyone can take or leave a book. But in the early pandemic, some people replaced books with canned goods, toilet paper, cleaning supplies and yarn and needles to give away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Convincing Win That Was Anything but Convincing
description: Manchester City had its way with Real Madrid — sort of. In the game’s aftermath, it was hard to shake the feeling that things had gone the other way.
content: MANCHESTER, England — First thing Wednesday morning, Pep Guardiola’s staff will deliver to the Manchester City manager a meticulously annotated report of his team’s Champions League semifinal against Real Madrid. At roughly the same time, Carlo Ancelotti, his counterpart in the Spanish capital, will receive something very similar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bruce Feiler
title: At a Place Where He Was Supposed to Be Safe, He Was Molested
description: In his memoir, “Chosen,” Stephen Mills recalls summers at a Connecticut camp led by a director who abused him while befriending his family.
content: Four centuries after arriving in America, Jews still worry about their place in this country; they pore over demographic surveys like Talmudic texts, looking for clues on how to forestall intermarriage and apathy. But in recent years, they’ve settled on an unlikely savior: Jewish summer camps. A 2011 study found that attendance at Jewish camps was one of the best predictors of increased engagement and religiosity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘The Skin of Our Teeth’ Review: A Party for the End of the World
description: Thornton Wilder’s antic play, from 1942, packs in an ice age, a deluge and midcentury décor. This Lincoln Center Theater production is the maximalist revival it deserves.
content: No fossil evidence suggests that a giant ground sloth ever composed a symphony or that a Devonian fish split the atom even once. And yet, have human beings really proved their worth? We have brought the world calculus, the sonnet, no-knead bread. But think of what we have inflicted: environmental devastation, species collapse, atrocities of various complexions. Humans keep surviving. We’re fit that way. But when you think about it — should we?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: What an Unvaccinated Sergeant Who Nearly Died of Covid Wants You to Know
description: Frank Talarico, a 47-year-old police sergeant, was hospitalized for 49 days with the coronavirus. “If I was vaccinated,” he said, “I have to think I wouldn’t have gotten as sick as I did.”
content: CAMDEN, N.J. — No one thought Frank Talarico Jr. was going to live. Not his doctors, his nurses or his wife, a physician assistant who works part time at the Camden, N.J., hospital where he spent 49 days fighting to survive Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Alphabet’s profit drops 8% as Google’s pandemic boom shows signs of slowing.
description: The results were below analysts’ expectations for a net profit of $17.33 billion on revenue of $68.05 billion.
content: Google’s pandemic boom may finally be slowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: U.S. military aims in Ukraine.
content: In a major shift, the U.S. toughened its messaging on the war in Ukraine yesterday, saying that the American aim was not just to thwart the Russian invasion, but also to weaken Russia so that it could no longer carry out such military aggression anywhere. Follow the latest updates on the war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ivan Krastev
description: Ezra interviews political scientist Ivan Krastev
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ivan Krastev. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen and Stacy Cowley
title: Senators question Zelle over how it is responding to reports of rising fraud.
description: Two Democrats called the reports “disturbing” and blasted Zelle’s operator, Early Warning, and its owners for creating a “confusing and unfair” situation for consumers.
content: Senators Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Bob Menendez of New Jersey took aim at Zelle, the popular money transfer app, on Monday, warning that it is putting millions of Americans at risk of being defrauded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: As mask mandates end, Canada’s Atlantic provinces see a virus resurgence.
description: Once relatively shielded from the virus transmission waves that flooded the rest of Canada, coronavirus infections are rising in the easternmost provinces.
content: In Canada’s Atlantic provinces, once a refuge of sorts from the pandemic, there has been a resurgence of known coronavirus infections at a time when most provinces have ended mask mandates and scaled back data surveillance on virus transmission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: The maker of Ray-Ban sunglasses has sued JPMorgan over $272 million in fraudulent payments.
description: The French maker of Ray-Ban sunglasses, Essilor International, has sued JPMorgan Chase for failing to stop the suspicious payments.
content: Essilor International, the French maker of Ray-Ban sunglasses, has sued JPMorgan Chase for failing to stop $272 million in fraudulent transfers from its New York bank account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan
title: Kenneth Roth, ‘Godfather’ of Human Rights Work, to Step Down
description: Mr. Roth joined Human Rights Watch when it was a fledgling organization. It has expanded into one of the most influential human rights advocacy groups.
content: Kenneth Roth said he first learned about human rights abuses from his father, whose Jewish family ran a butchery near Frankfurt in Hitler’s Germany. His father, Mr. Roth recalled, would describe how the Nazis forced the Jews into segregated schools, a precursor for much worse to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: What to Know About the 2022 N.F.L. Draft
description: Could the Jets trade down? Are any quarterbacks worth taking? Here’s what could happen in Las Vegas as the draft begins on Thursday.
content: The first round of the 2022 N.F.L. draft, the most important date in the league’s off-season, begins on Thursday, and this time with more than the typical pomp and circumstance from the glitz of being set in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson and David McCabe
title: On Twitter, conservatives celebrate, and progressives cringe, about Musk’s ownership of Twitter.
description: Members of the far right started testing the limits, tweeting misleading information about masks or pushing false claims about the 2020 election results.
content: When Elon Musk reached a deal to buy Twitter on Monday, he promised to return free speech and debate to the platform, saying it was “the bedrock of a functioning democracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Put Out a Grease Fire
description: Starve it of oxygen. If the kitchen is on fire, get out and close the door behind you.
content: “Frying chicken is a common culprit,” says Bruce D. Bouch, a fire-program specialist at the U.S. Fire Administration. Cooking is the leading cause of residential fires, and burning grease is particularly dangerous. When you see oil smoking in a pan, it’s on the verge of combustion. Animal fats like lard tend to smoke around 370 degrees Fahrenheit, while vegetable oils like safflower oil catch fire upward of 450 degrees. Always watch hot oil on the stovetop. “If you get on the phone, start texting, answer the door — that’s when fires occur,” Bouch says. “If you have to walk away, turn your burner off.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dalia Azim
title: ‘Omniscient yet Impotent,’ These Ghosts Linger
description: From a mysterious suicide to P.T.S.D. to a folkloric antihero: Four new novels explore different kinds of haunting.
content: In Chantal V. Johnson’s emotionally complex debut, POST-TRAUMATIC (312 pp., Little, Brown, $28), Vivian, the 30-something daughter of a Black father and Puerto Rican mother, works as a state-appointed attorney for minors in a public psychiatric ward in New York City. A survivor of sexual abuse as a child, Vivian has deep empathy for her young, often rage-filled clients, and a healthy skepticism of the system that keeps many of them hospitalized. When a friend comments that Vivian is “doing God’s work,” she answers with a critique of the American Psychiatric Association’s reference guide to diagnosing mental disorders: “Working hard to dismantle that D.S.M.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Beth Keane
title: In Squad We Trust: When a Church Committee Yields Unexpected Discovery
description: One year, eight members, many meetings. The setup for Michelle Huneven’s new novel, “Search,” sounds like a reality show, and it’s equally entertaining.
content: SEARCHBy Michelle Huneven
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: What Do Hepatitis Symptoms Look Like in Children?
description: The C.D.C. issued an alert after clusters of severe hepatitis cases popped up among children around the globe. What signs should parents watch out for?
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued an alert on Thursday to physicians nationwide notifying them of a cluster of severe and unexplained hepatitis cases in otherwise healthy young children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Ouyang
title: Can Virtual Reality Help Ease Chronic Pain?
description: V.R. treatments may provide relief similar to intravenous opioids — a tantalizing prospect for the millions of Americans living with chronic pain.
content: After an hour-and-a-half bus ride last November, Julia Monterroso arrived at a white Art Deco building in West Hollywood, just opposite a Chanel store and the Ivy, a restaurant famous for its celebrity sightings. Monterroso was there to see Brennan Spiegel, a gastroenterologist and researcher at Cedars-Sinai who runs one of the largest academic medical initiatives studying virtual reality as a health therapy. He started the program in 2015 after the hospital received a million-dollar donation from an investment banker on its board. Spiegel saw Monterroso in his clinic the week before and thought he might be able to help alleviate her symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Hughes
title: Is It Time to Try Speed Dating?
description: Several new companies are catering to app-fatigued singles — in some cases, at a steep price.
content: “We believe you are all sitting at the table because you bring something to it,” Lily Montasser told the room at the Jane Hotel in the West Village on a Thursday in late March. The group — 10 men, 10 women — had come for a night of cocktails, getting-to-know-yous and, hopefully, some romance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Vann
title: A Couple Self-Isolate for Seven Years, and Become One Person
description: In Sara Baume’s poetic novel “Seven Steeples,” Bell and Sigh’s world is reduced to each other, their dogs and the looming mountain they never climb.
content: SEVEN STEEPLESBy Sara Baume
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: The Biden Student Debt Question: Will He or Won’t He?
description: Some advocates believe President Biden’s repeated extensions of the repayment pause, now set to end Aug. 31, could force his hand on loan forgiveness.
content: Justin Nelson’s letter, one of the thousands that arrived at the White House this month, said he was proud to vote for President Biden back in 2020. Now he had a request: Would the president please honor a campaign promise and use the enclosed pen to wipe out thousands of dollars he owes in student loans?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Explosions rattle a breakaway region in Moldova, raising fears of a broader war.
description: The blasts in Transnistria, a region bordering Ukraine that is run by Russia-backed separatists, have fueled talk of Moldova being dragged into the war.
content: BRUSSELS — A series of explosions on Monday and Tuesday has rattled Transnistria, a small breakaway region within Moldova and bordering Ukraine, ramping up fears that the war next door could spill over into neighboring countries and swell into a wider conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Putin May Not Like How He’s Changed Europe
description: The political scientist Ivan Krastev discusses how European identity is transforming right now.
content: Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine has transformed Europe within a matter of weeks. A continent once fractured by the refugee crisis is now taking in millions of refugees. Countries such as Germany have made considerable pledges to increase military spending. The European Union said it would cut off Russian oil and gas “well before 2030” — a once unthinkable prospect. The European project seems more confident in itself than at any other time in recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Antisemitic Attacks in New York Are at Highest Level in Decades
description: Last year there were 51 assaults across the state, a record since the Anti-Defamation League began compiling such data in 1979.
content: Orthodox Jews assaulted on busy streets in Midtown Manhattan and in quiet neighborhoods in Brooklyn. Swastikas drawn on a Long Island home and spray painted onto Wall Street’s Charging Bull statue. A bomb threat against a Jewish community center in Albany, and fliers in Dutchess County that warned residents, “Jews want to take your guns.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: ‘Washington Crossing the Delaware’ Is Up for Sale. (Not That One.)
description: It’s a smaller version of the giant painting at the Met in New York, and it hung in the White House for years. Christie’s thinks it could sell for at least $15 million next month.
content: “Washington Crossing the Delaware,” a painting that portrays one of the most recognizable scenes of the American Revolution, is for sale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: A Gymnast’s Death Was Supposed to Be a Wake-Up Call. What Took So Long?
description: Christy Henrich’s struggle with eating disorders launched a reckoning in sports, but progress has been slow.
content: In the uneven bars final at the 1989 World Championships, Christy Henrich came within five-hundredths of a point of perfection. It was a beautiful routine, capped with a dismount perfectly stuck, and Henrich grinned as she waited for her score.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua M. Sharfstein
title: Congress Has to Ask How Much McKinsey Hurt the F.D.A.
description: Three critical questions to secure F.D.A. integrity.
content: The managing partner of the global consulting firm McKinsey will testify before Congress on Wednesday to respond to a stunning congressional report revealing that his company’s consultants were simultaneously working for Purdue Pharma, the manufacturer of the opioid OxyContin, and the Food and Drug Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Stella Tan, Eric Krupke, M.J. Davis Lin, Rachel Quester, Marion Lozano, Brad Fisher, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How a Sudden Mask Ruling Left the C.D.C. Reeling
description: An obscure lawsuit in Florida could endanger the federal health agency’s ability to intervene in future crises.
content: In January 2021, one of President Biden’s first big moves in office was to sign an executive order mandating masks in airports and on planes and other forms of public transit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
title: U.K. Tabloid Accuses Lawmaker of ‘Basic Instinct’ Move, Highlighting Sexism in Parliament
description: Citing an unnamed Conservative lawmaker, the paper claimed that Angela Rayner, a Labour leader, tried to distract Boris Johnson with her body. Fury has ensued.
content: LONDON — An anonymously sourced report by one of Britain’s freewheeling tabloid newspapers has sparked a debate over both tabloid journalistic ethics and sexism in Parliament, leading some to question whether the institution is capable of shedding its fusty reputation and becoming an inclusive workplace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coralie Kraft
title: With ‘Roar,’ the Creators of ‘GLOW’ Got Extra Personal. And Weird.
description: A surreal new series by Liz Flahive and Carly Mensch tells eight separate tales about women, including one who is mansplained to by an aggressive duck.
content: ALTADENA, Calif. — The first episode Liz Flahive and Carly Mensch wrote for their new Apple TV+ series, “Roar,” was also the most intimate. In the episode, a woman played by Cynthia Erivo returns to her demanding job after the birth of her second child. Soon after, she discovers strange bite marks on her body. In one unnerving, surreal moment, she pulls a human tooth out of the back of her hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman and Stanley Reed
title: Nuclear Power Could Help Europe Cut Its Russia Ties, but Not for Years
description: The projects, which some European countries are pushing to end their reliance on Russia’s energy, face delays in coming online.
content: PARIS — On the windswept coast of Flamanville, an industrial city in northwest France facing the choppy waters of the English Channel, a soaring concrete dome houses one of the world’s most powerful nuclear reactors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: G.M.’s profits fell 3% in the first quarter as chip shortages limited production.
description: Revenue for the first three months of the year jumped 11 percent from a year earlier, the automaker reported.
content: General Motors said on Tuesday that its profits dipped in the first three months of the year. But the company said it expected to grow rapidly as it started selling a wider range of electric cars and trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Coronavirus Has Infected More Than Half of Americans, the C.D.C. Reports
description: But prior infection does not guarantee protection from the virus, officials said, and Americans should still get vaccinated and boosted.
content: Sixty percent of Americans, including 75 percent of children, had been infected with the coronavirus by February, federal health officials reported on Tuesday — another remarkable milestone in a pandemic that continues to confound expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lia Picard
title: Let’s Have a (Disco) Ball
description: In these unsettling times, a twirling party from the ceiling can be an effective pick-me-up.
content: A hair salon set in a former church is unexpected. Add a chandelier made of at least 20 disco balls? That’s a good time, says Yoshi Burke, the salon’s owner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: The new White House Covid czar says avoiding all virus infections isn’t the goal of U.S. pandemic policy.
description: The more important reflections of progress, Dr. Ashish K. Jha said, would be whether health care systems are strained, and whether people are hospitalized with and dying from Covid-19.
content: Dr. Ashish K. Jha, the White House’s new Covid-19 coordinator, said on Tuesday that as the United States sees an increase in known coronavirus cases and keeps a watchful eye for new variants, the administration was not seeking to stop every infection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Microsoft reports rising revenue and profits, despite war and inflation.
description: Its sales of $49.4 billion in the first quarter were up 18 percent from a year earlier.
content: Despite inflation and uncertainty over the war in Ukraine, Microsoft on Tuesday reported financial results that showed little threat to the fundamentals of its business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Beijing’s Mass Testing Plan
description: Plus more aggressive support for Ukraine and Hong Kong’s brownface controversy.
content: Faced with a growing number of coronavirus infections across Beijing, city officials are trying to test most of the Chinese capital’s 22 million residents in the hope of avoiding the pain of imposing a citywide lockdown like in Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Harvard Details Its Ties to Slavery and Its Plans for Redress
description: The university is committing $100 million for an endowed “Legacy of Slavery Fund.” Its report carefully avoided treading on direct financial reparations for descendants of enslaved people.
content: In one column are the names of more than 70 enslaved people at Harvard: Venus, Juba, Cesar, Cicely. They are only first names, or sometimes no name at all — “the Moor” or “a little boy” — of people and stories that have been all but forgotten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philippe Marlière
title: France Is Still in Trouble
description: Emmanuel Macron won, but the far right isn’t going anywhere.
content: France can breathe again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay, Christopher F. Schuetze and Michael Levenson
title: As Diplomacy Hopes Dim, U.S. Marshals Allies to Furnish Long-Term Military Aid to Ukraine
description: Germany said it would send Ukraine dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles, a major shift for a country that has been reluctant to escalate the conflict with Russia.
content: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, Germany — The United States marshaled 40 allies on Tuesday to furnish Ukraine with long-term military aid in what could become a protracted battle against the Russian invasion, and Germany said it would send dozens of armored antiaircraft vehicles. It was a major policy shift for a country that had wavered over fear of provoking Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alla Katsnelson
title: Cultivating Coveted Morels Year-Round and Indoors
description: Jacob and Karsten Kirk, twins from Copenhagen, say they have devised a method to reliably grow morel mushrooms in a climate-controlled environment.
content: When new buds emerge on trees and the ground warms with the advent of spring, foragers fan out through woodlands, scanning the leaf litter for morel mushrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Russia cuts off a major supply of natural gas to Poland and Bulgaria.
description: The moves are Moscow’s first open targeting of Europe with denial of energy.
content: WARSAW — Infuriated by the West’s supply of arms and other support to help Ukraine resist invading Russian troops, Moscow on Tuesday took the fight to Europe’s economy, telling Poland and Bulgaria that it was halting supplies of natural gas, on which both countries and Europe in general are heavily dependent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Drusilla Modjeska
title: Looking to the Past, an Artist Finds a Soul Mate in Gwen John
description: Celia Paul’s “Letters to Gwen John” is a conversation between two artists — one living, one dead — about creativity, loss and the long shadows of famous men.
content: LETTERS TO GWEN JOHNBy Celia Paul
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Hyper-Specific Mother’s Day Brunch Recommendations
description: Because no two moms are the same.
content: Figuring out where to take the mom(s) in your life for brunch is no easy task. No two moms are alike! Some just want a nice, quiet place where they can hear themselves think, others prefer a booth over a chair that doesn’t offer long-term sitability. And if small kids are coming — it’s going to be a whole thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Eleven Madison Park Gets Into the Meal Kit Game
description: For $150 per week, Eleven Madison Home will deliver a day’s worth of ready-to-eat, plant-based meals to customers with Manhattan ZIP codes.
content: Last year the chef Daniel Humm converted Eleven Madison Park, his much-lauded palace of haute cuisine, into a palace of haute, plant-based cuisine. Now he is offering training wheels for vegan dining: Eleven Madison Home, a weekly subscription box to the tune of $150 ($285 for two) that includes a day’s worth of meals, with breakfast, lunch, dinner, dessert and snacks, most of it ready-to-serve. (Weekly delivery is only available for Manhattan addresses so far.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Climate Queries, Asked and Answered
description: Paris? Volcanoes? Computer models? Reporters from the Climate Desk tackled a wide range of intriguing questions sent by readers.
content: We hear you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
title: Standing in the path of war, a small Ukrainian town braces as Russians advance.
description: In Orikhiv, near the front lines, most residents have fled and those who remain endure constant shelling and the fear of what comes next.
content: ORIKHIV, Ukraine — Squeezed between the Ukrainian and Russian front lines in an increasingly volatile battlefield in southeastern Ukraine, the small town of Orikhiv is constantly under fire, and Tamara Mikheenko, one of the few residents who remain, rarely leaves her basement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James B. Stewart
title: Selling Twitter to Elon Musk Is Good for Investors. What About the Public?
description: The company’s decision to sell seems to have been based purely on the financials, with little if any regard for other stakeholders.
content: Twitter is “the digital town square, where matters vital to the future of humanity are debated,” a triumphant Elon Musk proclaimed in announcing his deal to buy the social media platform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Parents File Lawsuit Over Son’s Fatal Fall From Amusement Ride
description: Tyre Sampson, 14, died after falling from the 430-foot-tall Free Fall ride at an amusement park in Orlando, Fla., last month. The lawsuit says a seatbelt could have saved his life.
content: The parents of a 14-year-old Missouri boy who fell to his death from a ride in Florida in March have sued the amusement park, the ride’s operators and its manufacturer for negligence, saying there were no seatbelts or warnings about height and weight restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Stocks drop 2.8%, led lower by tech, as April’s slump continues.
description: Big technology companies are set to report earnings starting Tuesday. The S&P 500 has dropped nearly 8 percent this month, its worst monthly showing since March 2020.
content: Stocks slid on Tuesday, adding to a losing streak that has April shaping up to be Wall Street’s worst month in two years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Callahan
title: Why Do Carbs Give Me Headaches?
description: Experts say we may be thinking about food triggers for migraines and other kinds of headaches the wrong way.
content: Q: Why do carbs and sugar give me headaches?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura van Straaten
title: Can a New Art Space Refresh a Tired Downtown?
description: Bosco Sodi’s new museum in New York’s Catskill Mountains will feature artists from around the world and perhaps add some glimmer to a place that time has frayed.
content: MONTICELLO, N.Y. — Like its sister towns nestled nearby in the Catskill Mountains, signs are everywhere that the cultural and economic heydays of this seat of Sullivan County were deep in the past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Fidelity’s New 401(k) Offering Will Invest in Bitcoin
description: The employer that oversees the retirement savings plan would have to decide to include the digital assets account.
content: Fidelity, the nation’s largest provider of 401(k) plans, said on Tuesday that it would enable its participants to put a slice of their retirement money into Bitcoin — if their employers are willing to allow it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Why U.S. Oil Companies Aren’t Riding to Europe’s Rescue
description: American energy production has only inched up because executives fear that oil and gas prices won’t stay high.
content: HOUSTON — Oil and gasoline prices are climbing. Energy company profits are surging. President Biden, who came into office promising to reduce the use of fossil fuels, has effectively joined the “drill, baby, drill” chorus. Europe would love to end its dependence on Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: New York Democrats Make Last-Ditch Bid to Save New Congressional Maps
description: The state’s highest court heard arguments on Tuesday on whether to uphold earlier rulings that voided maps drawn by Democrats as illegal gerrymanders.
content: New York Democrats made a last-ditch appeal to the state’s highest court on Tuesday to overturn a pair of lower-court rulings and salvage newly drawn congressional districts that overwhelmingly favor their party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Hot Job Market, an Economic Relief, Is a Wall Street Worry
description: This year’s decline in stock prices follows a historical pattern: “When unemployment is ultra low, the uppity times are behind us,” a bank research chief said.
content: The U.S. unemployment rate is 3.6 percent — only a hair above its level just before the pandemic, which was a 50-year low. Corporate profits rocketed by 35 percent in 2021, and profit margins were at their widest since 1950. Yet stocks have been hammered lately: Two key stock indexes, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, have been deep in negative terrain since the start of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Is a Kitchen Island Essential? No, but You Know You Want One.
description: Here’s how to design an island that works for your particular space and the way you use your kitchen.
content: As the kitchen evolved from a work space hidden from guests to the place where everyone wants to congregate, the kitchen island became a must-have for many homeowners.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Willy Staley
title: Elon Musk Is a Typical Twitter User, Except for One Thing
description: The platform has always been the perfect place to indulge your whims. But when you’re the richest man in the world, those whims can grow significantly.
content: In many ways, Elon Musk uses Twitter like the rest of us. He likes to joke around, but isn’t as funny as he thinks he is; he overshares and loves memes; he occasionally goes too far, and gets himself in trouble; he seems to think the platform is unfairly suppressing the views of people with whom he identifies. Thanks to the flattening effects of Twitter, the only real difference between the site’s median user and Musk is about $257 billion and 85.4 million followers. He has more followers than Narendra Modi, the prime minister of the largest democracy on Earth, and fewer than Taylor Swift. No one in the history of the modern world has ever been as wealthy as he is. He also thinks the number 420 is so funny that he seems to have determined the final value of his offer ($54.20 per share) to accommodate its inclusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. Hershey Jr
title: Geraldine Weiss Dies at 96; Blazed a Trail for Women in Investing
description: She published her stock market newsletter for nearly four decades — initially as “G. Weiss,” to conceal her identity as a woman in a male-dominated industry.
content: Geraldine Weiss, who, after being told by a succession of stockbrokers that she was best qualified for the secretarial pool, devised an unconventional moneymaking strategy that she used in becoming the first woman to launch a successful investment newsletter, died on Monday at her home in the La Jolla area of San Diego. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mona El-Naggar and The New York Times
title: Baking Challah in Dubai: A Jewish Community Heads Out Into the Open
description: The increasing openness of Jewish life in the Persian Gulf emirate of Dubai is another sign of an emerging new reality in the Middle East, where Israel’s isolation by the Arab world is ebbing.
content: DUBAI — Two rows of tables covered in glossy runners, mixing bowls, wooden spatulas and containers of yeast, sugar, eggs, oil, flour and salt lined the garden of a villa set to host nearly 60 women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: Musk’s Twitter: Weed Memes. Editable Tweets. And the Return of Trump.
description: The newest social media honcho will face a bevy of business challenges at Twitter.
content: So, Elon Musk finally claimed his Twitter plaything.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anand Giridharadas
title: Elon Musk Is a Problem Masquerading as a Solution
description: What happens when the incarnation of a problem buys the right to decide what the problem is and how to fix it?
content: It is a perfect marriage for an age of plutocracy: Twitter with its serious problems and Elon Musk, the embodiment of those problems. What happens when the incarnation of a problem buys the right to decide what the problem is and how to fix it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Boodman
title: I Can Always Feel Like I’m Back Home in Montreal by Tapping My Feet
description: A useful trick for someone who always feels a little out of place.
content: When I was 17 or so, I worked evenings at a dentist’s office. At first, it carried the thrill of a secret world: The office building was locked — just me and the janitors and the whir of the autoclave. Then it was stultifying. I worked for only two hours at a time, but those two hours stretched out endlessly, a canvas for my teenage dread and insecurity. The families I was calling with appointment reminders often mistook me for a machine. I was there to develop some kind of work ethic, but all I could think about was the awful, oobleck-like quality of time. I tried singing between calls. I looked for constellations in the ceiling tiles. What I remember working best — what still works, when I feel the trapped-bug flutter of a panic attack starting up — is foot percussion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli and Scott Cacciola
title: The Nets and the Lakers Did Not Win. But Superteams Never Die.
description: The stars did not align in Brooklyn or Los Angeles this time, but it’s certain that someone will try again. Kyrie Irving is already making plans.
content: The game was over, and the crowd at Barclays Center was chanting “M-V-P.” The fans wore N.B.A. jerseys in all of the team’s colors, and their star raised his arms to acknowledge their praise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Coronavirus cases leave Senate Democrats temporarily without the votes they need to get some business done.
description: In an evenly divided Senate, neither party can afford to be without a single member.
content: A trio of positive coronavirus tests scrambled the Senate schedule on Tuesday, as Democrats lost the votes they needed to advance multiple nominees this week in an evenly divided Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Holds Military Parade With Nuclear Threat
description: In a speech, Kim Jong-un, the country’s leader, vowed to expand his nuclear arsenal ​“at the fastest possible speed​.”
content: SEOUL — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, vowed to expand his nuclear arsenal “at the fastest possible speed​” and threatened to use it, as his government displayed a large array of missiles and other weapons, including its newest intercontinental ballistic missile, during a nighttime military parade on Monday, the North’s state media said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy and Charlie Savage
title: Who helped end the travel mask mandate in the United States?
description: When the federal mandate requiring masks to be worn on planes and other public transportation crumbled last week, it was not because of lobbying by established trade organizations, or the strident calls of Republican lawmakers, or even a determination by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that masks were no longer necessary.
content: When the federal mandate requiring masks to be worn on planes and other public transportation crumbled last week, it was not because of lobbying by established trade organizations, or the strident calls of Republican lawmakers, or even a determination by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that masks were no longer necessary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Weed
title: Why Wait for a Sink When You Can Install an Entire Bathroom?
description: Amid growing shortages caused by global supply chain delays, developers are turning to prefabrication — the use of premade building parts like walls, staircases and even bathrooms.
content: When Deryl McKissack, the chief executive of the design and construction firm McKissack & McKissack in Washington, heard that electrical switch gear needed for the new Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport terminal was delayed because of supply chain issues, she knew the project would not come to a halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: McCarthy Feared G.O.P. Lawmakers Put ‘People in Jeopardy’ After Jan. 6
description: New audio recordings reveal Kevin McCarthy worried that comments by his far-right colleagues could incite violence. He said he would try to rein in the lawmakers, but has instead defended them.
content: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, feared in the aftermath of the Jan. 6 attack that several far-right members of Congress would incite violence against other lawmakers, identifying several by name as security risks in private conversations with party leaders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Spitzer
title: No Way to Say Goodbye
description: When my mother got Covid in April 2020, I learned what we lose over text.
content: My mother wasn’t a texter. When she first bought an iPhone in 2019, her texts came out garbled, with baffling spaces between words. She told me repeatedly that the format eluded her. Could I please call her instead, for God’s sake!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Wade
title: Six Artists Balance Creativity and Motherhood. Results Vary.
description: In Julie Phillips’s group portrait, Alice Neel, Doris Lessing, Ursula Le Guin, Audre Lorde, Alice Walker and Angela Carter take on making art while parenting.
content: THE BABY ON THE FIRE ESCAPECreativity, Motherhood, and the Mind-Baby ProblemBy Julie Phillips
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Carnegie Hall’s New Season: What We Want to Hear
description: The presenter is planning a return to full-scale programming for its 2022-23 season. Our critics and writers chose 15 highlights.
content: After scaling back its current season as it grappled with disruptions brought on by the coronavirus pandemic, Carnegie Hall announced on Tuesday that it would return to full programming next season with a slate of more than 150 concerts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Beijing Starts Testing Most Residents to Try to Avoid a Lockdown Like Shanghai’s
description: China’s capital reported 22 cases as it kicked off an ambitious mandatory testing campaign across the city and reassured residents that food and other supplies were plentiful.
content: BEIJING — Faced with a growing number of coronavirus infections across Beijing, city officials are trying to test most of the capital’s 22 million residents in the hope of avoiding the pain of imposing a citywide lockdown like in Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: A Nameless Soldier, a Shameless Politician and a Soulless Leader
description: Ukrainians fight for freedom as a U.S. congressman and Russia’s leader fight for power.
content: I am thinking about three people today whose behavior could have a significant impact on the world in the coming months and possibly years: a soldier with no name, a politician with no shame and a leader with no soul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Who Goes There?
description: Simon Marotte’s puzzle is a (head)banger.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Happy Tuesday, solvers! Today’s puzzle is from the constructor Simon Marotte, who is making his third appearance in the New York Times Crossword. This puzzle is oriented a little differently from your typical Tuesday (more on that below), which may affect the way you move through the grid. It certainly affected my solve — in the best way. I love when constructors play with conventions to make me approach a puzzle in a new way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: Banh Mi in a Drive-Through? Vietnamese Restaurants Reach for Fast-Food Success.
description: From a former KFC to a 1950s-style drive-in, owners see the quick-service window as a portal to a wider audience.
content: HOUSTON — The Hughie’s on West 18th Street is one among scores of Vietnamese American restaurants around this city. But it may have more in common with a Dairy Queen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Elon Musk and the Gray of ‘Free Speech’
description: He wants Twitter to allow more speech. We’ve got questions.
content: The internet as we know it is a constant act of choosing some speech over others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dinaw Mengestu
title: How Does One Find Meaning and Love in a World Full of Ills?
description: Zachary Lazar’s new novel, “The Apartment on Calle Uruguay,” examines the ambiguous relationships we have with harsh political realities.
content: THE APARTMENT ON CALLE URUGUAYBy Zachary Lazar
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: New Details Underscore House G.O.P. Role in Jan. 6 Planning
description: A court filing and newly disclosed text messages provide additional evidence of how closely some fervent pro-Trump lawmakers worked with the White House on efforts to overturn the election.
content: WASHINGTON — It was less than two weeks before President Donald J. Trump’s staunchest allies in Congress would have what they saw as their last chance to overturn the 2020 election, and Representative Scott Perry, Republican of Pennsylvania, was growing anxious.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Kevin Hart’s Media Company Sells $100 Million Stake to Private Equity
description: The deal with Abry Partners is the latest example of private equity’s pushing into Hollywood to cash in on the demand for streaming shows.
content: Kevin Hart has heard the doomsaying about the streaming industry that has rattled Hollywood since Netflix reported last week that it had lost subscribers in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson, Amy Chang Chien and Isabelle Qian
title: ‘I Just Want to Help’: Amid Chaos, Shanghai Residents Band Together
description: As the authorities in China’s biggest city fight to stamp out an Omicron outbreak, neighbors are turning to one another for support.
content: Four days into a coronavirus lockdown in her Shanghai neighborhood, Ding Tingting began to worry about the old man who lived alone in the apartment below her. She knocked on his door and found that his food supply was dwindling and that he didn’t know how to go online to buy more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Judge Orders Man Who Defaced L.G.B.T. Pride Mural to Write Essay on Pulse Shooting
description: Alexander Jerich, who pleaded guilty to causing damage to the mural in South Florida, must write a 25-page essay about the 2016 attack on a gay nightclub in Orlando.
content: A man who admitted to defacing an L.G.B.T.Q. pride mural in South Florida has been ordered by a judge to write a 25-page essay about the Pulse nightclub shooting, an unorthodox assignment that surprised local rights activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: PepsiCo says revenues jumped after it raised prices.
description: Thanks to price increases at many of its popular drink and snack brands, PepsiCo reported strong first-quarter revenues.
content: Thanks to double-digit percent increases for the prices of many of its popular snack and beverage products, PepsiCo saw a big jump in revenues in the quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: How Can I Teach When I’m Not Allowed to Shut Down Trolls?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to navigate new state laws restricting classroom discussions.
content: I’m a professor at a branch campus of a large state-university system in a state that has passed — and is planning to pass more — laws dictating what (and how) we can teach in our classrooms. These laws are intentionally vague and allow almost any material related to several important topics to be called into question. This has emboldened a small but very vocal part of our student body to disrupt classrooms whenever issues of race, gender, religion or sexuality are raised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Jenny Gross and Anna Schaverien
title: What’s Next for Elon Musk and Twitter
description: Twitter has accepted the $44 billion takeover offer, but there are plenty more questions to be answered about the company’s future.
content: Elon Musk has succeeded in convincing Twitter to accept his takeover offer, which would make the world’s richest man, who runs the most valuable car company, the owner of one of the most influential social networks. The $44 billion Twitter deal is set to be the biggest leveraged buyout in at least two decades, according to Dealogic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Uses Clemency Powers for the First Time
description: The president commuted the sentences of 75 nonviolent drug offenders and issued three pardons, part of what aides described as a broader strategy to overhaul the criminal justice system.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Tuesday used his clemency powers for the first time to commute the sentences of 75 drug offenders and issue three pardons, including to the first Black Secret Service agent to work on a presidential detail, who had long maintained he had been wrongfully convicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: What ‘Severance’ Is Made of: ‘Being John Malkovich’ and a Sizzler Steakhouse
description: The creator of the sci-fi thriller drew on Kurt Vonnegut, “Black Mirror” and a ’90s restaurant commercial to build the show’s disquieting sets and nightmare logic.
content: For some employees, what happens at Lumon stays at Lumon. In the world of the Apple TV+ series “Severance,” they have agreed to let the company implant them with a chip that splits their personality so that one side remembers only what happens at the office and the other exists only on the outside. Work and life are so perfectly balanced that never the twain shall meet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Kono, Yakitori From an Expert, Opens in Manhattan’s Chinatown
description: Mike Solomonov and Steve Cook’s latest arrives in Brooklyn; an Eataly Downtown spot pivots; and more restaurant news.
content: Omakase, a type of Japanese meal that leaves the selection of dishes up to the chef, is most often associated with a parade of sushi bites. But it is also applied to yakitori at this restaurant from Atsushi Kono, an expert in yakitori, or “grilled bird,” usually skewered chicken. Mr. Kono was the executive chef of Yakitori Torishin in New York starting in 2006, having spent time working in Japan. Now he is opening his own place, where he will serve yakitori omakase as he presides over grills fueled with the binchotan charcoal frequently used in Japanese cooking. He takes center stage, surrounded on three sides by a dramatically lit counter that seats 14 people for set $165 dinners at 5:30, 6, 8:30 and 9 p.m. (Beverages, tax and tip are extra.) Various parts of organic chickens, including the heart, oyster, soft knee cartilage, tail and tenderloin, are grilled on bamboo skewers as the centerpiece of the meal. Chicken thigh roulade, chicken pâté and soups are also served, with a black sugar crème brûlée as the finale. Wagyu, king crab and Iberico pork are among the optional extras. The restaurant also has a table seating four to six.
